Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Geological Constraints on ~25 Million Years of Magmatism Along an Arc-transform Junction, Wrangell Volcanic Belt, Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Wrangell volcanic belt in southern Alaska is situated in a complex tectonic environment where an oceanic plateau (the Yakutat block) is presently colliding with and subducting beneath Alaska at a very low angle. To the east, a large transform fault system, the Denali fault, bounds the edge of this subducting plateau and a major volcanic chain, the Wrangell volcanic belt that has been built up over the last 25 million years, marks this intersection. Such junctions are common in modern convergent margin settings and the resulting volcanic belts record both variations in relative position of the leading front of the slab and translation of the upper plate along strike-slip faults. The processes that generate lavas in these complex settings are poorly understood. Here, this research team aims to decipher the origins of the volcanic rocks in the Wrangell volcanic belt through a comprehensive study of the geology, volcanic rock chemical composition, and geochronology of the belt. The results would provide a new understanding of how volcanic chains develop in such complex tectonic settings. The project also benefits society or advances desired societal outcomes through: (1) planned involvement of students from underrepresented minorities in STEM; (2) increased public scientific literacy and public engagement with science and technology through presentations in local communities and development of interpretive materials for the Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve; and (3) development of a STEM workforce through training of graduate and undergraduate students and support of early career researchers.

This project examines the geochemical-eruptive evolution of an under-sampled 25 Ma arc-transform magmatic belt, the Wrangell volcanic belt in Alaska. The belt is transected by a major strike-slip fault, the Denali fault system, and located above both the edge and leading front of the Yakutat flat slab. The researchers will collect bedrock, detrital sand/cobbles samples, and sedimentological and structural data from the Wrangell volcanic belt. They will determine major and trace element composition, whole rock Sr, Nd, Pb, and Hf, and zircon Hf-isotope concentrations, and 40Ar/39Ar and U/Pb geochronology on bedrock and detrital samples. Specific objectives of the project are to: (1) determine the temporal-spatial history of magmatism of the Wrangell volcanic belt; and (2) decipher the links between strike-slip faulting, and slab melting on the geochemical evolution of this slab edge volcanic belt. These data will be integrated with geological mapping to provide important new constraints on the development of slab edge magmatism along an arc-transform junction as the leading front of the flat slab progresses inboard and the relationship between strike-slip faults and the geochemistry of magmatic products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While driving the Alaska’s Tok Cut off, Richardson or Glen Highways the > 16,000 feet Wrangell Volcanos block out the horizon. Wrangell volcano (~215 km3) alone has six times the volume of Mount Rainer (~36 km3). Perhaps not surprising one of the longest line of sight views in the world is from the top of a Wrangell Volcano (Mount Sanford) to Denali 221 miles away (standing on an oceans edge your line of sight is about 3 miles). These giant volcanoes not only fill the horizon but have the potential to spew ash across the globe and affect air traffic.

 

Why the Wrangell volcanos exist and why they are so big has been an ongoing debate among geophysicists and hard rock geologists since the 1970’s.  A recent publication cumulating the collaborative work by faculty and students from UAF, Kansas State, and Bucknell Universities provides answers to both questions. This team of geochronologists and geochemists spent 3 summers executing field work in Wrangell National Park and performing laboratory analysis back at their Universities. They discovered that all the Alaska Wrangell Volcanos are subduction related and hence an arc volcano belt and have been continuously active for 30 million years which is very unusual for a subduction related volcanic belt, where there usually are long periods of no volcanic activity. The size and frequency of eruptions of the Wrangell Volcanic arc is related in part to the volcanic belt's position above the edge of a subducting plate (the Yakutat) which is subducting at a low angle (16 degrees). The combination of the increased surface area of the flat slab at the optimal depth for the production of magmatism and mantle flow over the edge of the slab has led to an optimal environment to produce large volcanoes. Additionally, the region's strike-slip faults (Denali and Totschunda) are acting as conduits for magma transport. 

 

The Wrangell Volcanic field lays over a region referred to as arc-transform junction: where a plate bounding strike-slip fault and a subduction related volcanic belt intersect. Our research demonstrates that these areas can produced long-lived arc volcanic belts with unusual geochemistry (adakitic) due to slab edge melting. These special arc volcanic belts  not only produce extremely large shield volcanos, but also arc volcanic belts that more elliptical in foot print than “arc shaped”, as is the case of the Wrangell arc.

 

During this National Science Foundation funded project we developed a novel detrital lithic grain 40Ar/39Ar approach on modern river sediments to help constraint the age of the Wrangell Volcanic field. We also implemented a combined 40Ar/39Ar and geochemistry approach on clasts collected from rivers surrounding the Wrangell Volcanic field to better capture the petrogenesis history of the region. We presented our results at national (AGU and GSA) and regional meetings (GSA) and this project resulted in two master theses to date. We have published one manuscript so far and two are under-review and three more are in preparation.

We provided expert advice on the geology of Wrangell National Park to the park service, assisted with newspapers articles on the research project, answered correspondence from the public on the geology of the Wrangell Volcanos and gave a presentation in the remote town of McCarthy through the Wrangell Mountain Center.
